headline: CNN Newsroom
subHeadline: Alex Murdaugh Cross-Examined For Second Day In His Murder Trial. Aired 3:30-4p ET

utterances.speaker: ALEX MURDAUGH, MURDER DEFENDANT
utterances.sentences: I tried to get a man to help me kill myself because issues were at my doorstep.

utterances.speaker: CREIGHTON WATERS, PROSECUTOR
utterances.sentences: Every time -- I'm sorry, for the first time in your life of privilege and prominence and wealth, when you were facing accountability each time, suddenly you became a victim and everyone ran to your aid. Isn't that true?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I disagree with that. But -- and -- what you're saying --

utterances.speaker: EDWARDS
utterances.sentences: For you is extraordinary provocation, isn't that true, Mr. Murdaugh?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Let me just finish this. You seem to be implying two dates, June 7 and September and talking about accountability issues and, I mean, those, to me, those two things are totally different. There were no accountability issues on my doorstep on June 7.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: That's what you say.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: And in September --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Not what other people say.

utterances.speaker: MILGRAM
utterances.sentences: -- I was trying to -- well, no? I mean, been a lot of people in September that wasn't designed to gain me sympathy. That was designed for me not to be here because I didn't want my son to have to deal with the wake of the things that I had done.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: But that's not the story you told. The story that came out of your mouth right away was the story of you getting attacked by some unknown assailant while you were trying to change a tire and run flat. That's the story that you told.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That is the story I told, but that's because the man who shot me did not shoot me that day as I intended. And I had to have a story as to how I got shot. So I lied.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: So you lied. And you're saying that people in your family and your friends didn't instantly believe that whoever these 12 year old marauders were, were back to finish the job.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: You keep using --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: It happen just two hours after you've been confronted by Chris Wilson?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I think probably some people may have thought that when it first happened, but I think Randy, Ronnie, Mark, those guys, I think they knew very quickly that this was not -- I think they knew this was something that I'd done.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Shame for you. I asked this before, but shame for you is an extraordinary provocation, isn't it, Mr. Murdaugh?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Shame for me is an extraordinary provocation, I don't like to be shamed.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: The prospect of humiliating the legacy is an extraordinary provocation to you, isn't it, Mr. Murdaugh?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: What do you mean by an extraordinary provocation?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: It affects you deeply. It's your biggest concern, is it not?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, that's not my biggest concern.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You're a middle aged man like me.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm 54 years old. I'm not sure. You look like you're in better shape than me. So, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I was actually a couple of years behind you in law school. But we never knew each other, did we?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I never knew you know, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Had a very successful career, up until this point. It's a simple question.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: And the answer to that is no, Mr. Waters. I was an addict for more than 20 years.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. So making millions of dollars over a decade is not having a successful career, is that what you're going to tell the jury?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, that's not a successful career. When you --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK, well, let me put it like that.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, hang on. Let me just --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: You know, it may have been what you perceive as a successful career, but, you know, I was the one who was fighting that. You don't have a very high self-esteem when you're an addict, so I don't deem myself a success. [15

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Would you agree that at least outwardly, you're perceived as successful?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I made a bunch money, if that's what you want to get at.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: No, I'm actually asking about the perception. You were perceived as a prominent --

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I tried to be.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: -- powerful lawyer.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: How I was perceived --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You're president of the trial lawyer.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I sure tried to be.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Lived a life of possessing authority?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Possessing authority?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. We saw the badges. You just admitted of your prominence in the legal community.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't think that I lived a life of possessing authority. I never saw myself as that way.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You don't think you lived a life of privilege?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I think I was very privileged.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: But as we moved to June of 2021, you were suffering from a drug addiction?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Your father was terminally ill?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: When? I mean --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: As we moved to June of 2021?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir. He --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: He was very ill.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: He was very ill.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And you were coming to a point of financial crisis?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I was having financial issues like I'd had many times in the past.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Mr. Murdaugh, are you a family annihilator?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: A family annihilator? You mean like, did I shoot my wife and my son?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No. I would never hurt Maggie Murdaugh. I would never hurt Paul Murdaugh, under any circumstances.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You say that.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Excuse me?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You say that you lied to Maggie, didn't you?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did lie to Maggie.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You lied to Paul?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Sometimes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You lied to your father?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm sure I did at some point.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you tell him all the stuff you had been up to over the years before he died?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, I didn't tell him.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you lie to your brothers?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: About financial things?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I would have lied to Randy at some point, I'm sure. W WATERS

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you lie to their wives?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm sure I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did July to Marian Proctor?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you lie to Bart Proctor?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you lie to the Branstetters? MURDAUGH

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you lie to your best friend Chris Wilson?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Probably.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you lie to your other friend Barrett Boulware when you took his money?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Not -- I didn't lie I told you. I didn't lie directly to him. I lied to him by a mission, like we talked about him and he was -- I didn't talk to him. I didn't see him at that time.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you lie to your law partners?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you lie to him about the kennels?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Some of them.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you like to Mark Ball?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes. Based on what Mark said, I believe I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you lie Ronnie Crosby?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: According to what he said, I believe I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you lie to Johnny Parker?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't believe I ever discussed that with Johnny.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you lie to him about the finances when you borrowed that money in July of 2021?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't know if I lied to him about -- I don't -- Johnny. I don't think Johnny asked me. I don't think I had to lie to Johnny about that, so I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you lie -- well, you didn't certainly didn't disclose to him the truth when you borrowed that $250,000, did you?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I mean, didn't we have say before that not telling the whole truth is the same as telling the lie?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Sure it is.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You don't think that's a lie, though?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't. I'm just saying -- Mr. Waters, I'm not taking issue with that, but I don't even know that Johnny and I -- I mean, Johnny had loaned me money numerous times. It wasn't any long sit down discussion where Johnny wanted to know exactly what I was doing with it.That conversation would have been, I needed it. Johnny was always willing to help me, and that would have been the conversation. So on that specific event, did I lie to him? I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: He ended up being out $477,000, didn't he?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: He ended up being out a lot of money.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Thank you for your qualifications as to that. Did you lie to Lee Cope?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I don't know if Lee Cope was around when I said that or not.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you lie to Danny Henderson?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did lie to Danny.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you lie to Jeanne Seckinger?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't -- about finances, yes, I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You didn't ever talk to her about the kennels?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, I wouldn't think so.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you lie to Annette Griswold?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you lie to Christie Gerald, your other secretary for paralegal.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't believe she and I discussed. I would have at some point, I'm sure.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you lie to Michael Gunn?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm sure I did at some point, but, I mean, Michael wasn't involved in any of this, so I don't know that any of this ever came up with Michael.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you lie to your clients? Did you lie to Pamela Pinckney?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Natasha Thomas?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't know that I dealt with Natasha, but I certainly lied about that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Hakeem Pinckney?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Again, I don't know that I talked to Hakeem, but I certainly lied about that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Arthur Badger?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: The Plyler girls?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That's -- I'm not sure that I talked specifically to them, but I lied about that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Deon Martin?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I lied to Deon.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Johnny Bush?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Manuel Cristiani?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I didn't have any conversations with him, but I certainly lied about it.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Jamie Risharp (ph)?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Randy Drawdy?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Jordan Jinks?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Marie Duncan?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Audrey Onahay (ph)?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Angel Gary?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Christopher Anderson?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Elisa Mallory?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Thomas Moore?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You never lied to him? You just took his money. He never had to actually lie to his face, is what you're saying?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: He and I never had a conversation, but I did take that money.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did July of Tony Satterfield just a couple of months before June 7? We saw the text. You want me to get it out?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Just remind me. There's been a lot. Just remind me what it was.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I'll show you what's been marked as 463.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: And I don't remember the exact date, so.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: That was in April of 2021. Is that right?

utterances.speaker: BIANNA GOLODRYGA, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: OK, we're going to take you back to the Walterboro, South Carolina courtroom.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Lied to everyone about the side of the road? The people that came to stop to help, and the ambulance, folks, and the 911, and Ryan Kelly and the composite sketch artists and all them, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I lie to a lot of people about that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You know why people lie, Mr. Murdaugh? Because they know they've done something wrong.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: For the most time I do.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And you've been able to lie quickly and easily and convincingly if you think it'll save your skin for well over a decade. Isn't that true?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I have lied well over a decade.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And you want this jury to believe a story manufactured to fit the evidence that you brought forth just yesterday after hearing this trial is worth the testimony?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir, that's not correct.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Mr. Murdaugh, we went through this for a while, but you remember at the beginning of your testimony, I asked you whether or not you agreed that trying to explain your presence on the kennel video was the most important part of your testimony before this jury. You remember that? And you said, oh, not the most important. And I said, was it the least important? You recall that from yesterday?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I recall you asking those questions, yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And you agree it's important, don't you?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I agree that as an important component, but I think there's a lot of important components.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And you testified yesterday during cross yesterday and cross today, it's kind of evolved on the fact of the factors that led you to decide to lie at some point during that interview with David Owen, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I disagree with that. I don't think those factors have evolved. I mean, you've asked some more specific questions, but those factors are still the same factors. You may have asked questions and gained a little more detail, but those factors haven't changed.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: But it was the dope paranoia. It was the fact that the deputy took your GSR. It was the fact that your law partners and Greg Alexander and the sheriff were telling you you needed to have a lawyer before you talk to police. It was a factor that you got in the car with Dave Owen and thought he was somebody else from some case 10 years ago. Correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That believing David Owens was the person involved in the case that I talked about was one of the factors that caused me to distrust SLED.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right, and then also you said that they started asking you about, in that first interview, about your relationship with Maggie and Paul, and that's one thing you mentioned as well. Correct?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Are we good?(OFF-MIC)

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE) the Daniel Greene body cam video 2026?(BEGIN AUDIO CLIP) (OFF-MIC) MURDAUGH: All right. The police are here now. The police are here now. That's it bro. SGT. DANIEL GREENE, COLLETON COUNTY: OK. When was the last time you were here with them or talked to them or anything like that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: It was earlier tonight. I don't know the exact time, but --

utterances.speaker: GREENE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: -- I left -- I was probably gone an hour and a half for my mom's, and I saw them about 45 minutes before that.(END AUDIO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: That was Sergeant Greene, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, that was Sergeant Greene.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And at that point in time, SLED was not there. No one had gotten GSR from you. Your law partners, or Sheriff Hill were not there?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: No one had asked you about your relationships. David Owen was not there.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: But you still told the same lie. And all those reasons that you just gave this jury about the most important part of your testimony was a lie, too. Isn't that true, Mr. Murdaugh?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I disagree with that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Nothing further.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Ladies and gentlemen, to take a break now. Please do not discuss the case.

utterances.speaker: GOLODRYGA
utterances.sentences: And we have just been listening to what appears to be the prosecution wrapping in its cross examination of Alex Murdaugh and his murder trial.Let's bring back CNN's Dianne Gallagher outside the courthouse in South Carolina. Still with us, CNN's Jean Casarez and CNN Legal Analyst Joey Jackson. Also with us. Defense Attorney Misty Marris. Misty, to you firs, since you're new to this conversation with us on this program, talk about what you heard from the prosecution specifically at the end, wrapping it up by once again reiterating just about to everybody in Murdaugh's life he had lied to.

utterances.speaker: BLACKWELL
utterances.sentences: Jean, to you, what stood out to you in this last segment we've heard from Creighton Waters in this cross examination?

utterances.speaker: JEAN CASAREZ, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Well, it was powerful. And I think we now fully understand why he's focused so much on these financial crimes, because he's trying to show, just as Misty said, that you've lied to everyone in your life and professionally for decades, and you then lied that you were not down at the kennels, so the jury should not believe you.And the net result is you were down there exactly when the murders happened, and so you're guilty. And that's what he's trying to leave the jury with, because if you're down there, there's nobody else down there. And that's when the iPhones locked for the very last time. They were murdered right at that time. And that's what his focus is.

utterances.speaker: GOLODRYGA
utterances.sentences: All right, our coverage will continue. I want to thank our guests for joining us this hour. The Lead with Jake Tapper starts right after this short break.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
